senses.sense_definition: A tall wooden pole decorated with flowers, greenery, and ribbons, around which people dance during traditional May Day celebrations.

examples.text: The children gathered on the village green to dance around the <w>maypole</w>.
Colorful ribbons were woven into complex patterns as the dancers circled the <w>maypole</w>.

senses.sense_definition: A very tall and thin person, typically a young woman.

examples.text: She felt like a <w>maypole</w> standing next to her much shorter friends.
He teased his sister for growing into a <w>maypole</w> over the summer.

senses.sense_definition: A structure made of sticks built around a sapling by certain species of bowerbirds to attract a mate.

examples.text: The male golden bowerbird constructs an elaborate <w>maypole</w> to impress potential mates.
Researchers observed the bird decorating its <w>maypole</w> with lichen and flowers.

senses.sense_definition: A penis, especially one of large size.

examples.text: The bawdy novel used the term <w>maypole</w> to describe the character's anatomy.
He made a crude joke comparing himself to a <w>maypole</w>.

senses.sense_definition: To move, dance, or spin in a circle around a central point or object.

examples.text: The excited puppy <w>maypoled</w> around my legs when I got home.
The fishing line <w>maypoled</w> itself around the rod, creating a tangled mess.

senses.sense_definition: A name used for several settlements in England and Wales, such as in Kent, Greater London, or Monmouthshire.

examples.text: They visited a small village called <w>Maypole</w> during their trip to Kent.
The map shows a settlement named <w>Maypole</w> near the coast.
Mr. <w>Maypole</w> was known for his bakery in the town square.
We looked up the <w>Maypole</w> family history in the local archives.
